p: mRNA carries the genetic information as an intermediate, which can be used as a template for protein production in the vaccinated subject, endogenously [ 57]. Non- replicating mRNA and Self-amplifying mRNA are the two major types of RNA that have been used so far as prophylactic vaccines against infectious disease-causing pathogens [ 58]. The sequence of the specific antigen is flanked by the 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions (UTRs) in the non-replicating mRNA [ 58]. The advantage of non-replicating mRNA over self-amplifying mRNA is that they have a small size, simpler construct, and lack any extra encoded proteins, which could trigger an unwanted immune response [ 59].
